newsitem.title: USA: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Expiration week starts off slow.
newsitem.headline: US OPTIONS FOCUS/Expiration week starts off slow.

text.p: The July expiration week got off to a slow start Monday, but traders said a late-session move could once again enliven the market.
"It's kind of slow, but volatility's high," said one trader in the S&P 500 index .SPX options pit.
"We'll probably get our 12 to 15 point move in today," he said. "I don't know which way, but we'll get it."
Sharp market moves in the last hour of trading are nothing new, but traders said the regularity of such moves is new.
July options expire at the end of the week.
By about 1140 CDT/1640 GMT, the SPX was up 4.11 at 920.79, off the 921.78 session high but above its 916.68 low. September S&P 500 futures were up 3.25 at 927.65.
Among other major indexes, the Dow industrial average .DJI gained nearly 20 points to 7,941 and the S&P 100 .OEX added 5.64 to 899.23.
Traders said volatility in July index options would likely remain high for the beginning of the week but would drop sharply into the expiration.
The volatility index .VIX, which is priced off certain front-month OEX contracts, was up 0.40 at 22.43 Monday.
One index option trader said late-session moves were not uncommon but their increased regularity was helping to keep volatilities pumped up.
Options analysts said early indications showed solid underlying strength for the market heading into this week's expiration.
Jerry Hegarty, an analyst at Thomson Financial Services, said through the 14 trading days of the July expiration cycle, nearly 400,000 index puts have traded compared to calls.
"This accumulation should help push stock prices higher this week," he said in a report.
But if index options activity was suggesting investor caution, other sentiment measures were still showing high bullishness.

"Wall Street is wildly bullish," Chris Cadbury said in his daily market letter. He noted that last week, three sentiment surveys all showed investor bullishness at 70 percent or higher for the first time ever.
He forecast the SPX to end the week at 916 or lower.
